keyTakeAways: A massive cloud computing outage on Amazon Web Services (AWS) disrupted global internet services, including social media, gaming, food delivery, streaming, and financial platforms.
The root cause was identified as a problem in AWS’s domain name system (DNS), which converts web addresses to IP addresses, leading to a failure in website and app access.

More than 2,500 companies reported outages, with over 11 million user reports collected by DownDetector, including Snapchat, Roblox, Fortnite, Robinhood, McDonald’s app, Netflix, Disney+, and Coinbase.

Educational platforms like Canvas were significantly impacted, with college and K-12 students unable to access course materials or submit assignments, affecting institutions like the University of California, Riverside and Ohio State University.
Amazon’s own services, such as Ring doorbell cameras, Alexa smart speakers, and Kindle book downloads, were also affected, illustrating the breadth of AWS’s reach.

Cybersecurity expert Mike Chapple and IT professor Patrick Burgess emphasized that such outages are typically due to technical issues, not cyberattacks, and are resolved within hours via standard recovery processes.
The incident underscores the growing dependence of modern society on a few dominant tech companies for critical internet infrastructure, creating systemic vulnerability when these services fail.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A major outage of Amazon Web Services (AWS) on October 20, 2025, disrupted internet services worldwide, including social media, gaming, financial platforms, and education systems. The outage, which began around 3:11 a.m. Eastern time and was resolved by 6 p.m. Eastern time, was traced to a failure in AWS’s domain name system (DNS). Over 11 million users reported disruptions across more than 2,500 companies, including Snapchat, Roblox, Fortnite, Robinhood, Netflix, Disney+, Coinbase, and Signal. Educational platforms like Canvas were also affected, preventing students from accessing coursework and submitting assignments at institutions such as the University of California, Riverside and Ohio State University. Amazon’s own services, including Ring and Alexa, were impacted. Experts like Mike Chapple and Patrick Burgess noted that such outages are typically due to technical issues and resolved within hours, not cyberattacks. This incident underscores the growing vulnerability of modern society to a few dominant tech companies providing critical internet infrastructure.
